title: Quiz 14: Immunization KEPI
description: NCK 2025 Predictions for Immunization KEPI (Set 5). Contains 50 questions.

questions.question: What is the primary goal of KEPI?

options.text: ) To provide nutrition supplements to children
) To ensure universal access to vaccines for preventable diseases
) To provide antibiotics for infectious diseases

questions.explanation: KEPI aims to reduce morbidity and mortality from vaccine-preventable diseases by providing universal immunization coverage, especially among children.

questions.question: Which vaccine is given at birth as part of the KEPI schedule?
questions.explanation: The Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG) vaccine is administered at birth to protect against tuberculosis, especially severe forms in children.

questions.question: How many doses of Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) are given during the KEPI schedule?
questions.explanation: OPV is administered at birth, 6 weeks, 10 weeks, and 14 weeks, totaling four doses as per the KEPI schedule.

questions.question: Which of the following vaccines is administered at 9 months of age in KEPI?
questions.explanation: The measles vaccine is given at 9 months to provide immunity before the child reaches an age of high exposure risk.

questions.question: Which vaccine protects against diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus?
questions.explanation: The DPT vaccine targets diphtheria, pertussis (whooping cough), and tetanus, three serious bacterial infections.

questions.question: What is the route of administration for the BCG vaccine?
questions.explanation: BCG vaccine is given intradermally, which means into the skin’s superficial layer to stimulate an immune response.

questions.question: Which vaccine is NOT part of the traditional KEPI schedule?
questions.explanation: While Rotavirus vaccine has been introduced in some immunization programs, it is not part of the original traditional KEPI schedule.

questions.question: At what age is the first dose of DPT vaccine given in the KEPI schedule?
questions.explanation: The first dose of DPT is given at 6 weeks, followed by doses at 10 and 14 weeks.

questions.question: What is herd immunity?

options.text: ) Immunity achieved only by vaccinated individuals
) Protection of the entire community when a high proportion is immune
) Immunity transferred from mother to child

questions.explanation: Herd immunity occurs when enough people in a population are immune to a disease, reducing its spread and protecting those who are not immune.

questions.question: Which vaccine is given orally in KEPI?
questions.explanation: The Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV) is administered by mouth to induce immunity against poliovirus.

questions.question: Which disease does the BCG vaccine primarily protect against?
questions.explanation: BCG vaccine protects mainly against tuberculosis, particularly severe forms in children.

questions.question: Why is the measles vaccine given at 9 months rather than earlier?

options.text: ) Because maternal antibodies interfere before 9 months
) Due to availability of the vaccine

questions.explanation: Maternal antibodies present in infants under 9 months can neutralize the measles vaccine, so it is given at 9 months when immunity develops better.

questions.question: What type of vaccine is the DPT vaccine?
questions.explanation: The DPT vaccine contains toxoids for diphtheria and tetanus and killed whole cells for pertussis; the diphtheria and tetanus components are toxoids (inactivated toxins).

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a vaccine-preventable disease covered under KEPI?
questions.explanation: Malaria is not vaccine-preventable by the vaccines in KEPI; prevention involves other measures like insecticide-treated nets.

questions.question: How many doses of the measles vaccine are recommended in the expanded schedule?
questions.explanation: Two doses of measles vaccine are recommended to ensure long-lasting immunity, usually at 9 months and at 15 months.

questions.question: Which of these vaccines is typically given intramuscularly?
questions.explanation: The DPT vaccine is administered intramuscularly, commonly in the thigh or deltoid muscle.

questions.question: What is a cold chain in immunization programs?

options.text: ) A system to keep vaccines at recommended temperatures during storage and transport

questions.explanation: The cold chain is critical to maintain vaccine potency by ensuring they remain within recommended temperature ranges from manufacture to administration.

questions.question: Which vaccine in KEPI protects against hepatitis B?
questions.explanation: The hepatitis B vaccine prevents hepatitis B virus infection and its complications like liver cirrhosis and cancer.

questions.question: What is the recommended spacing between the three doses of DPT vaccine?
questions.explanation: The three doses of DPT vaccine are typically spaced 4 weeks apart to ensure effective immunity development.

questions.question: Which of the following is a contraindication to administering live vaccines?
questions.explanation: Live vaccines are contraindicated in severely immunosuppressed individuals as they may cause infection due to weakened immunity.

questions.question: What is the primary method to monitor the success of immunization programs like KEPI?
questions.explanation: Monitoring disease incidence rates allows assessment of vaccine effectiveness and overall program success.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common side effect of vaccination?

options.text: ) Mild fever and swelling at injection site
) Development of the disease being vaccinated against

questions.explanation: Mild fever and localized swelling or pain are common side effects; severe reactions are rare.

questions.question: What is the importance of the “drop-out rate” in immunization programs?

options.text: ) Percentage of children who receive the first vaccine dose but not the subsequent doses
) Number of children who miss school

questions.explanation: The drop-out rate indicates children starting but not completing vaccination, a key factor in program effectiveness.

questions.question: Which of these is a benefit of immunization?
questions.explanation: Immunization protects individuals and communities against infectious diseases, reducing illness and mortality.

questions.question: What does “vaccine efficacy” refer to?

options.text: ) How easy the vaccine is to administer
) The percentage reduction of disease in vaccinated individuals compared to unvaccinated

questions.explanation: Vaccine efficacy measures how well a vaccine prevents disease under controlled clinical trial conditions.

questions.question: Which vaccine prevents tetanus?
questions.explanation: The DPT vaccine includes tetanus toxoid to prevent tetanus infection.

questions.question: Which of these is a strategy to improve immunization coverage in Kenya?

options.text: ) Outreach and mobile clinics in remote areas

questions.explanation: Outreach and mobile clinics help reach underserved populations, increasing vaccine coverage.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of live attenuated vaccines?

options.text: ) They contain weakened forms of the pathogen
) They require multiple doses every year
) They may be contraindicated in immunocompromised patients

questions.explanation: Live attenuated vaccines generally provide long-lasting immunity after one or two doses, not requiring yearly boosters like some inactivated vaccines.

questions.question: Which vaccine is given intradermally in KEPI?
questions.explanation: BCG is administered intradermally.

questions.question: How can vaccine-preventable diseases be eradicated?

options.text: ) By vaccinating a majority of the population and maintaining high coverage
) By treating all cases with antibiotics
) By focusing only on symptomatic patients

questions.explanation: Eradication requires high vaccine coverage to interrupt disease transmission.

questions.question: What does “cold chain break” mean?

options.text: ) When vaccines are exposed to temperatures outside recommended ranges
) When the immunization schedule is missed

questions.explanation: Cold chain breaks compromise vaccine potency due to improper temperature control.

questions.question: Which vaccine is recommended for pregnant women to protect newborns against neonatal tetanus?
questions.explanation: Tetanus toxoid vaccination in pregnancy prevents neonatal tetanus by transferring maternal antibodies.

questions.question: What is the purpose of vaccine adjuvants?

options.text: ) To enhance immune response to the vaccine

questions.explanation: Adjuvants boost the body's immune response to the antigen in vaccines.

questions.question: Which of these vaccines requires booster doses in later childhood?
questions.explanation: The DPT vaccine requires booster doses after the primary series to maintain immunity.

questions.question: What is a “vaccine schedule”?

options.text: ) List of vaccines administered during outbreaks
) Timetable specifying timing and sequence of vaccine doses
) List of side effects of vaccines

questions.explanation: A vaccine schedule guides timing and intervals of vaccine administration for optimal immunity.

questions.question: Which vaccine is contraindicated in infants with severe allergic reactions to eggs?

options.text: ) Influenza (not part of KEPI but relevant)

questions.explanation: Influenza vaccines grown in eggs can trigger allergic reactions in egg-sensitive individuals.

questions.question: How is immunization status verified in children?
questions.explanation: Immunization cards provide a reliable record of vaccines received.

questions.question: What is the typical cause of vaccine failure?
questions.explanation: Vaccine failure can result from multiple factors including storage, schedule adherence, and administration.

questions.question: What disease does OPV protect against?
questions.explanation: OPV prevents poliomyelitis by inducing immunity to poliovirus.

questions.question: What is the common site of injection for infant DPT vaccine?
questions.explanation: The anterolateral thigh is the preferred site for intramuscular injections in infants.

questions.question: Which of the following vaccines is known to cause a "scar" at the injection site?
questions.explanation: BCG vaccination typically leaves a small scar, considered a sign of successful vaccination.

questions.question: What is the major reason for incomplete immunization in children?

options.text: ) Parental refusal or lack of awareness

questions.explanation: Parental refusal, lack of knowledge, or access issues are major barriers to full immunization.

questions.question: How should vaccines be stored during transport in KEPI?

options.text: ) In insulated containers with ice packs maintaining 2-8°C

questions.explanation: Vaccines must be kept cold but not frozen, typically between 2-8°C during transport.

questions.question: Which vaccine prevents Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) disease?
questions.explanation: The Hib vaccine protects against infections caused by Haemophilus influenzae type b bacteria.

questions.question: Why is immunization important in controlling infectious diseases?

options.text: ) It reduces disease transmission and severity

questions.explanation: Immunization reduces transmission and severity of infections, contributing to disease control.

questions.question: When is the third dose of the hepatitis B vaccine given in KEPI?
questions.explanation: The third dose is given at 14 weeks to complete the hepatitis B vaccination series.

questions.question: Which statement about vaccine side effects is true?

options.text: ) Severe side effects occur in most vaccinated children
) Most side effects are mild and temporary

questions.explanation: Most vaccine side effects are mild (e.g., fever, soreness) and temporary, serious effects are rare.

questions.question: Which group is most prioritized in KEPI?
questions.explanation: KEPI primarily targets infants and young children due to their vulnerability to vaccine-preventable diseases.

questions.question: Which of the following vaccines is given at birth to prevent perinatal infection?
questions.explanation: The hepatitis B vaccine given at birth prevents transmission from mother to child during birth.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the second dose of the measles vaccine?

options.text: ) To prevent side effects from the first dose
) To boost immunity in case of primary vaccine failure

questions.explanation: The second dose ensures protection in children who did not respond to the first dose or whose immunity waned.
